title: Family of ‘Essex lorry victim’ say they ‘begged her not to go’
text:
The family of a woman who is feared to be one of the Essex lorry victims ‘begged her not to go’

The family of a young woman thought to be one of the 39 people found dead in a refrigerated lorry in Essex say they pleaded with her not to make the journey.

Pham Tra My, 26, was last in contact with relatives on Tuesday when she sent them a text message saying she could not breathe.

In the early hours of Wednesday, authorities found bodies of eight women and 31 men in the back of a lorry in Grays.

Driver, Maurice Robinson, 25, is due in court on Monday to answer 39 charges of manslaughter and charges of conspiracy to traffic people, assist unlawful immigration and money laundering.

Three other people arrested were released on bail earlier on Sunday.

A man and woman from Warrington were released on bail until November 11 while a man from Northern Ireland has been bailed until November 13, police said.

Vietnamese woman Pham Tra My is feared to be among the 39 people found dead

Ms Tra My’s relatives said they have not heard from her since she sent the text message.

She’s believed to have paid around £30,000 to get into the UK illegally.

Her father, Pham Van Thin, told Sky News he and other family members urged her not to go.

He said: ‘We tried to talk her out of it because it would be a very difficult journey for her as a girl.

‘But she said: ‘If I don’t go, the family would stay in a very difficult situation because of the big debt’.

‘So she took a risk and decided to go, and we had to agree.’

He revealed the smugglers said the crossing was ‘a safe route’ and said he thought people would travel by aeroplane or car.

Mr Van Thin added: ‘If I had known she would go by this route, I would not have let her go.’

More than 20 of the victims are thought to be from Vietnam.

All have been moved to Broomfield Hospital in Chelmsford for post-mortem examinations and formal identification to be carried out.

Investigators are still due to sift through more than 500 pieces of evidence, including mobile phones as they try to piece together what led to the tragedy.

Pham Van Thin (R) and Nguyen Thi Phong (L), father and mother of Pham Thi Tra My, fear their daughter is among the victims (Picture: EPA)

They are also investigating reports the lorry could have been in a convoy of three carrying around 100 people.

In Belgium, police are hunting the driver who delivered the trailer to Zeebrugge, the port it left before arriving in the UK.

It is not yet known when the victims entered the trailer, where temperatures can be as low as minus 25C if the fridge is activated, or the exact route it travelled.

description: Pham Tra My's family haven't heard from her since she texted on Tuesday and say they 'begged her' not to go on the journey to the UK.
